content:
So, can we do a bit of prep for the meeting later? I just wanted to brainstorm a bit about next steps. I've been thinking that maybe we can identify a couple of big goals?

I would propose

  • [x] Create compiler-team template
  • [ ] Create templates for the initial round of working groups
  • [ ] Identify a set of "procedures" to describe
  • [ ] Create "expert map" for the compiler and populate it
  • [ ] Create a "journeyperson" role and populate it with some initial folks (we wouldn't decide who those people are, that's probably a team decision, but I can get it started)

I don't quite know what that "journeyperson" role should mean yet -- but it seems like we can figure that out a bit incrementally? Having the list would already be great.
(cc @davidtwco, @Santiago Pastorino with whom I was talking about this recently)
That sounds good. I'll think a bit about these and draft some ideas.
Awesome!
Also, I was just thinking about the "minimum initial investment" in a WG -- I wrote this comment here, maybe worth talking that over too -- or that might be a steering meeting question.

I think it's worth thinking about how we get feedback from the team on our ideas. At the end of the day, they are leading the working groups and it's the team that'll feel the impact of how we decide to tackle the things on our idea list.
Yep
sounds good

Also, I was just thinking about the "minimum initial investment" in a WG -- I wrote this comment here, maybe worth talking that over too -- or that might be a steering meeting question.

yeah, I think it worth talking about this too
what's the meaning of Create templates for the initial round of working groups?
you mean setup the rest of the working groups with some basic info or what?
also, unsure what do you mean by expert map
we should list the expert people there and their areas of expertise?
I'm already writing some stuff down

what's the meaning of Create templates for the initial round of working groups?

Yes I meant: create, for each of the initial set of working groups we expect to have active, a directory
This is already in progress, of course.

we should list the expert people there and their areas of expertise?

Yes, though I think of it somewhat in reverse:

We list the areas of the compiler, and tag them with people
@WG-compiler-meta :point_up: we should establish a convention for "WGs centered around implementing an RFC", I expect..?

I quite liked @varkor's idea at the all hands about making a working group that's main focus is in implemeting RFCs rather than having a dozen smaller working groups for each one. It isn't as clear a goal as we normally aim for w/ working groups, but it stops there from being a ton of ongoing working groups.
(I created a calendar event in the compiler team calendar, and added you as an invitee @blitzerr.)
@davidtwco Yeah, maybe, I'm game for trying that too, although I think it makes sense more for "smaller" RFCs. This one is kind of in the middle for me, it could fit into such a group.
Perhaps, yeah. I think we could probably discuss where we roughly feel the line is so we don't spin up a working group and incur that overhead for every other task (which is, of course, exaggerated).
sounds like something we could discuss in the meeting maybe ?
(moved these messages into meeting topic, originally this message pointed to this message)
how do you do that btw?
Little dropdown next to a message, then "view source/edit topic" if it is someone else's message, or "edit" if it is yours. Then change the topic and use the dropdown that will appear.
Might need to be an admin for other people's messages, unsure.
